description: Scots, from Scottish Gaelic sprédh, spré, from Middle Irish preid, preit (“booty”) (plus mobile s-), borrowed from Latin praeda (“plunder, spoils; profit; prey”), thus a doublet of prey. Per one hypothesis, also a doublet of spree.

entries.meaning: (Scotland, obsolete) A raid in order to steal cattle.
examples: It was then as much the scene of continual spreaths, liftings, reavings, and herriments, as the Border country itself.
